title: Falcon 180B emission per token (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
In the absence of energy consumption data of Falcon 180B, this information is extrapolated from available data on Falcon 7B. The number of parameters in Falcon 7B is 7 billion, whereas Falcon 180B has a much larger parameter count of 180 billion.

Therefore, we assume that submitting a query to Falcon 180B requires 25x more energy.

title: Falcon 7B emission per token (Hugging Face)
description:
The Hugging Face LLM-Perf Leaderboard benchmarks the performance of large language models (LLMs). Energy consumption is measured using CodeCarbon. We observe that the most energy efficient Falcon model with 7B parameters handles 422,919 completion tokens/kWh.

Further note that in the Hugging Face experiment, the prompt size is 256 tokens, and the output size is 256 tokens, too. However, the "Energy" value refers to 1 generated completion token. As there is no reason to believe that prompt tokens consume no energy, we apply factor 0.5x here, but use both prompt and completion tokens for our calculation.

Per token, that's (1/422919)x0.5 = 1.2e-6 kWh.

title: Monthly carbon footprint of ChatGPT (Ludvigsen)
description:
Kasper Groes Albin Ludvigsen approximated the carbon footprint of ChatGPT. The calculation and the underlying assumptions he made are further illustrated in this carbon footprint scenario.

In January 2023, ChatGPT had about 100M unique users who made 590M queries to GPT-3. The estimated emissions associated with these requests have been modeled below. To explore further, adjust the quantity in the input field or click on the link.

title: Carbon footprint of one average query to GPT-3
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3, Ludvigsen relates to the large language model BLOOM instead. Both models are roughly the same size — 175b vs 176b parameters for GPT-3 and BLOOM respectively.

The experiment handled 230,768 queries in total, so the fraction for one request is 1/230768 = 4.3334e-6

title: BLOOM model experiment
description:
Alexandra Sasha Luccioni et al. published a study on the the carbon footprint of the BLOOM model. With its 176 billion parameters, BLOOM is a large language model (LLM) that is able to generate text in 46 natural languages and 13 programming languages. The researchers ran their experiment on 16 Nvidia A100 GPUs during 18 days. The model handled 230,768 queries in the course of the experiment. In total, the system consumed 914 kWh of electriciy for CPU, RAM and GPU usage.

For the emissions, we used a grid emissions factor for Western USA (WECC) from EPA.

title: Monthly carbon footprint of ChatGPT (Pointon)
description:
Chris Pointon approximated the carbon footprint of ChatGPT. The calculation and the underlying assumptions he made are further illustrated in this carbon footprint scenario.

In January 2023, ChatGPT had about 100M unique users who made 590M queries to GPT-3. The estimated emissions associated with these requests have been modeled below. To explore further, adjust the quantity in the input field or click on the link.

title: Carbon footprint of one average query to GPT-3 (Pointon)
description: Chris Pointon assumes that each query to ChatGPT generates in average 30 words.

title: Carbon emission of 1 output word generated by GPT-3
description:
Tom Goldstein, Professor at U of Maryland, extrapolates that if GPT-3 were to run on a single Nvidia A100 GPU, it would take 350 ms to output one word.

The fraction of such an operation of one hour is 350/3600000 = 9.7222e-5

title: Hourly emission by GPU running at full load
description:
The author assumes that ChatGPT is hosted in an Azure datacenter in California, running on Nvidia Tesla A100 GPUs.

Thus, he takes as starting point the energy consumption of this processor under full load as provided by Cloud Carbon Footprint (407 Watts per hour). For the emissions, he uses a grid emissions factor for Western USA (WECC) from EPA.

title: GPT-3 emission per token (Pointon)
description:
Tom Goldstein, Professor at U of Maryland, extrapolates that if GPT-3 were to run on a single Nvidia A100 GPU, it would take 350 ms to output one word.

The fraction of such an operation of one hour is 350/3600000 = 9.7222e-5

As this calculation ignores the impact of the prompt on the energy consumption, we assume an equal number of prompt tokens and apply factor 0.5x to obtain a per-token value.

title: Monthly carbon footprint of ChatGPT (Ruf & Mortas)
description: In this scenario, we approximate the carbon footprint of ChatGPT based on the Llama 2 model and energy consumption data from Hugging Face.

title: Carbon footprint of one average query to GPT-3 (Ruf & Mortas)
description: We assume that each query to ChatGPT generates in average 1,319 tokens.

title: GPT-3
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3, this information is extrapolated from the freely available language model Llama 2. The number of parameters in Llama 2 is 68.98 billion, whereas GPT-3 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion.

Therefore, we assume that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 2.5x more energy.

title: Llama 2
description: The Hugging Face LLM-Perf Leaderboard benchmarks the performance of large language models (LLMs). Energy consumption is measured using CodeCarbon. We observe that the most energy efficient Llama 2 model with 70B parameters handles 163,934 completion tokens/kWh. Per token, that's 1/163934 = 6.1e-6 kWh.

title: Llama 3
description: The Hugging Face LLM-Perf Leaderboard benchmarks the performance of large language models (LLMs). Energy consumption is measured using CodeCarbon. We observe that the most energy efficient Llama 3 model with 8B parameters handles 201,527 completion tokens/kWh. Per token, that's 1/201527 = 5.1e-6 kWh.

title: GPT-3 emission per token (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3, this information is extrapolated from the freely available language model Llama 3. The number of parameters in Llama 3 is 8 billion, whereas GPT-3 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion.

Therefore, we assume that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 21.9x more energy.

Further note that in the Hugging Face experiment, the prompt size is 256 tokens, and the output size is 256 tokens, too. However, the "Energy" value refers to 1 generated completion token. As there is no reason to believe that prompt tokens consume no energy, we apply factor 0.5x here, but use both prompt and completion tokens for our calculation.

title: GPT-3 emission per token (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3, this information is extrapolated from the freely available language model Llama 2. The number of parameters in Llama 2 is 68.98 billion, whereas GPT-3 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion.

Therefore, we assume that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 2.5x more energy.

title: Monthly carbon footprint of ChatGPT (Selvan)
description:
Raghavendra Selvan from University of Copenhagen approximated the carbon footprint of ChatGPT. The calculation and the underlying assumptions he made are further illustrated in this carbon footprint scenario.

In January 2023, ChatGPT had about 100M unique users who made 590M queries to GPT-3. The estimated emissions associated with these requests have been modeled below. To explore further, adjust the quantity in the input field or click on the link.

title: Monthly carbon footprint of ChatGPT (Selvan)
description:
Raghavendra Selvan from University of Copenhagen approximated the carbon footprint of ChatGPT. The calculation and the underlying assumptions he made are further illustrated in this carbon footprint scenario.

In January 2023, ChatGPT had about 100M unique users who made 590M queries to GPT-3. The estimated emissions associated with these requests have been modeled below. To explore further, adjust the quantity in the input field or click on the link.

title: GPT-3
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3, this information is extrapolated from a freely available open source language model (GPT-J). Scaling to GPT-3, the following factors are taken into account:

1. The number of parameters in GPT-J is 6 billion, whereas GPT-3 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion. By a conservative estimate, the larger model could require 10x additional GPUs.

2. To fit the test environment, the GPT-J model is initialized in half-precision. The overhead of running a full precision model compared to half precision is about 1.5x more.

Therefore, it is assumed that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 15x more energy compared to submitting a query to GPT-J.

title: Carbon footprint of one average query to GPT-3 (Selvan)
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3, this information is extrapolated from a freely available open source language model (GPT-J). Scaling to GPT-3, the following factors are taken into account:

1. The number of parameters in GPT-J is 6 billion, whereas GPT-3 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion. By a conservative estimate, the larger model could require 10x additional GPUs.

2. To fit the test environment, the GPT-J model is initialized in half-precision. The overhead of running a full precision model compared to half precision is about 1.5x more.

Therefore, it is assumed that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 15x more energy compared to submitting a query to GPT-J.

title: GPT-J
description:
To estimate the carbon footprint of GPT-J, a freely available language model with 6 billion parameters, Raghavendra Selvan ran experiments on a local workstation. The model was initialized in half-precision (16 bit float instead of 32 bit float) to fit into GPU memory. The average length of text generated by the model was 230 words. The energy consumption got measured with CarbonTracker, a tool developed by researchers from University of Copenhagen.

As a result, one request to GPT-J consumed in average 0.01292 kWh.

title: GPT-J
description:
To estimate the carbon footprint of GPT-J, a freely available language model with 6 billion parameters, Raghavendra Selvan ran experiments on a local workstation. The model was initialized in half-precision (16 bit float instead of 32 bit float) to fit into GPU memory. The average length of text generated by the model was 230 words. The energy consumption got measured with CarbonTracker, a tool developed by researchers from University of Copenhagen.

As a result, one request to GPT-J consumed in average 0.01292 kWh.

title: GPT-3 emission per token (Selvan)
description:
The outputs in this experiment generate in average 230 words. We apply factor 1/230 to get the emissions per completion token.

As this calculation ignores the impact of the prompt on the energy consumption, we assume an equal number of prompt tokens and apply factor 0.5x to obtain a per-token value.

title: Monthly carbon footprint of ChatGPT (de Vries)
description: One of the recent articles by Patel and Ahmed [31] assumes the number of active users for chatGPT to be 13 million and it was also assumed that 15 queries were made by each of the active users per day. = 195000000 per day

title: Carbon footprint of one average query to GPT-3 (de Vries)
description:
In the article 'The growing energy footprint of artificial intelligence' Alex de Vries from VU Amsterdam School of Business and Economics refers to estimations published in a blog post by SemiAnalysis. They suggest that OpenAI needed 3,617 of NVIDIA’s HGX A100 servers, totaling 28,936 graphics processing units (GPUs). From this, de Vries estimates a total energy demand of 564 MWh per day.

The same source also estimates that the number of daily active users is 13 million, with an average of 15 requests each, leading de Vries to estimate the average electricity consumption per request at 2.9 Wh. This aligns with a statement by Alphabet's chairman John Hennessy in February 2023, indicating that interacting with an LLM could 'likely cost 10 times more than a standard keyword search,' which was reported to be 0.3 Wh per query by Google in 2009.

Several reports, including one by Goldman Sachs Research and another by BestBrokers, base their studies on this calculation.

title: GPT-3.5 per token – Llama2 70B (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3.5, this information is extrapolated from the freely available language model Llama 2 70B. The number of parameters in Llama 2 70B is 68.98 billion, whereas GPT-3.5 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion.

Therefore, we assume that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 2.5x more energy.

title: GPT-3.5 per token – Llama2 7B (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3.5, this information is extrapolated from the freely available language model Llama 2 7B. The number of parameters in Llama 2 7B is 7 billion, whereas GPT-3.5 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion.

Therefore, we assume that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 25x more energy.

title: GPT-3.5 per token – Llama3 8B (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3.5, this information is extrapolated from the freely available language model Llama 3 8B. The number of parameters in Llama 3 8B is 8 billion, whereas GPT-3.5 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion.

Therefore, we assume that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 22x more energy.

title: GPT-4 per token – Llama2 70B (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
There is limited public information available about the technical structure of GPT4. Some sources suggest it is a Mixture of Expert (MoE) with 8 x 220 billion parameters.

In other MoE architectures with disclosed weights, it has been noted that the actual total number of parameters is lower than indicated by the architecture. Additionally, it has been observed that only a fraction of those parameters are actually active during inference. For example, the Mixtral-8x22B-v0.3 architecture reports a total of 140.6B parameters (80%), out of which 39.1B parameters are activated during inference (28%).

According to this information, we assume the same proportions for GPT-4 and thus estimate a total of 394.24 billion active parameters.

Finally, we extrapolate the energy consumption of GPT-4 based on a scenario for GPT-3.5 which is known to have 175 billion parameters, and therefore apply a factor of 2.25x.

title: GPT-4 per token – Llama2 7B (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
There is limited public information available about the technical structure of GPT4. Some sources suggest it is a Mixture of Expert (MoE) with 8 x 220 billion parameters.

In other MoE architectures with disclosed weights, it has been noted that the actual total number of parameters is lower than indicated by the architecture. Additionally, it has been observed that only a fraction of those parameters are actually active during inference. For example, the Mixtral-8x22B-v0.3 architecture reports a total of 140.6B parameters (80%), out of which 39.1B parameters are activated during inference (28%).

According to this information, we assume the same proportions for GPT-4 and thus estimate a total of 394.24 billion active parameters.

Finally, we extrapolate the energy consumption of GPT-4 based on a scenario for GPT-3.5 which is known to have 175 billion parameters, and therefore apply a factor of 2.25x.

title: GPT-4 per token – Llama3 8B (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
There is limited public information available about the technical structure of GPT4. Some sources suggest it is a Mixture of Expert (MoE) with 8 x 220 billion parameters.

In other MoE architectures with disclosed weights, it has been noted that the actual total number of parameters is lower than indicated by the architecture. Additionally, it has been observed that only a fraction of those parameters are actually active during inference. For example, the Mixtral-8x22B-v0.3 architecture reports a total of 140.6B parameters (80%), out of which 39.1B parameters are activated during inference (28%).

According to this information, we assume the same proportions for GPT-4 and thus estimate a total of 394.24 billion active parameters.

Finally, we extrapolate the energy consumption of GPT-4 based on a scenario for GPT-3.5 which is known to have 175 billion parameters, and therefore apply a factor of 2.25x.

title: GPT-4o-mini emission per token (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
Official information about the architecture of GPT-4o-mini is not available. In this scenario, we propose using our most optimistic energy consumption estimate made for GPT-4 and utilizing the price difference of both models as a proxy.

OpenAI charges different prices for input and output tokens. Due to the mechanism of key-value (KV) caching, output tokens need more memory and therefore consume more energy than input tokens. For this reason, use the price for output tokens as proxy.

Currently, 1 million output tokens of GPT-4-turbo cost $30, while they cost $0.6 for GPT-4o-mini. Therefore, we assume a query to GPT-4o-mini to require 50x less energy than for GPT-4.

title: GPT-4o emission per token (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
Official information about the architecture of GPT-4o is not available. In this scenario, we propose using our most optimistic energy consumption estimate made for GPT-4 and utilizing the price difference of both models as a proxy.

OpenAI charges different prices for input and output tokens. Due to the mechanism of key-value (KV) caching, output tokens need more memory and therefore consume more energy than input tokens. For this reason, use the price for output tokens as proxy.

Currently, 1 million output tokens of GPT-4-turbo cost $30, while they cost $10 for GPT-4o. Therefore, we assume a query to GPT-4o to require 3x less energy than for GPT-4.

title: Llama 2 70B emission per token (Hugging Face)
description:
The Hugging Face LLM-Perf Leaderboard benchmarks the performance of large language models (LLMs). Energy consumption is measured using CodeCarbon. We observe that the most energy efficient Llama 2 model with 68.98B parameters handles 163,934 completion tokens/kWh.

Further note that in the Hugging Face experiment, the prompt size is 256 tokens, and the output size is 256 tokens, too. However, the "Energy" value refers to 1 generated completion token. As there is no reason to believe that prompt tokens consume no energy, we apply factor 0.5x here, but use both prompt and completion tokens for our calculation.

Per token, that's (1/163934)x0.5 = 3.05e-6 kWh.

title: Llama 2 7B emission per token (Hugging Face)
description:
The Hugging Face LLM-Perf Leaderboard benchmarks the performance of large language models (LLMs). Energy consumption is measured using CodeCarbon. We observe that the most energy efficient Llama 2 model with 7B parameters handles 882,368 completion tokens/kWh.

Further note that in the Hugging Face experiment, the prompt size is 256 tokens, and the output size is 256 tokens, too. However, the "Energy" value refers to 1 generated completion token. As there is no reason to believe that prompt tokens consume no energy, we apply factor 0.5x here, but use both prompt and completion tokens for our calculation.

Per token, that's (1/882368)x0.5 = 5.7e-7 kWh.

title: Llama 3 8B emission per token (Hugging Face)
description:
The Hugging Face LLM-Perf Leaderboard benchmarks the performance of large language models (LLMs). Energy consumption is measured using CodeCarbon. We observe that the most energy efficient Llama 3 model with 8B parameters handles 761,789 completion tokens/kWh.

Further note that in the Hugging Face experiment, the prompt size is 256 tokens, and the output size is 256 tokens, too. However, the "Energy" value refers to 1 generated completion token. As there is no reason to believe that prompt tokens consume no energy, we apply factor 0.5x here, but use both prompt and completion tokens for our calculation.

Per token, that's (1/761789)x0.5 = 6.6e-7 kWh.

title: Mistral 7B emission per token (Hugging Face)
description:
The Hugging Face LLM-Perf Leaderboard does provide energy information for Mistral 7B v0.1 which generates 720,589 completion tokens/kWh in its most energy efficient version and has 7.3B parameters.

Further note that in the Hugging Face experiment, the prompt size is 256 tokens, and the output size is 256 tokens, too. However, the "Energy" value refers to 1 generated completion token. As there is no reason to believe that prompt tokens consume no energy, we apply factor 0.5x here, but use both prompt and completion tokens for our calculation.

Per token, that's (1/720589)x0.5 = 6.9e-7 kWh.

title: Mistral Large 2 emission per token (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
In the absence of energy consumption data of Mistral Large 2, this information is extrapolated from available data on Mistral 7B v0.1

The number of parameters in Mistral 7B is 7.3 billion, whereas Mistral Large 2 has a much larger parameter count of 123 billion.

Therefore, we assume that submitting a query to Mistral Large 2 requires 17x more energy.

title: Mistral Small emission per token (Ruf & Mortas)
description:
The Mistral Small model is not listed on the Hugging Face LLM-Perf Leaderboard which benchmarks the performance of large language models (LLMs) and measures the energy consumption using CodeCarbon. However, as Mistral open source the weights of their models, we know that Mistral Small has 22B parameters.

The leaderboard does provide energy information for Mistral 7B v0.1 which has 7.3B parameters. Accordingly, we propose to extrapolate this data and approximate the energy consumption of Mistral Small by applying a factor of 3x.

title: Paris to Dublin by train and ferry
description: Paris – London – Holyhead – Dublin

title: GPT-3
description:
In the absence of reliable data on the energy consumption of GPT-3, this information is extrapolated from a freely available open source language model (GPT-J). Scaling to GPT-3, the following factors are taken into account:

1. The number of parameters in GPT-J is 6 billion, whereas GPT-3 has a much larger parameter count of 175 billion. By a conservative estimate, the larger model could require 10x additional GPUs.

2. To fit the test environment, the GPT-J model is initialized in half-precision. The overhead of running a full precision model compared to half precision is about 1.5x more.

Therefore, it is assumed that submitting a query to GPT-3 requires 15x more energy compared to submitting a query to GPT-J.

title: Warming 1L of water from 18 to 38°C
description:
Before being heated, the temperature of the water in a tank is 18°C.
Most people take a shower at 38°C (a little bit above body temperature).

According to thermodynamic, heating 1L of water from 18 to 38°C consume 0.0232 kWh.

Formula: Energy [kWh] = (mass of water [g] x specific heat capacity [J/g°C] x delta T [°C]) / conversion coefficient [J/kWh]
Details: (1 000 x 4.18 x (38 - 18)) / 3 600 000 = 0.0232

title: 1 hot shower
description:
The average flow rate of a shower is 15L/minute. The average time for a shower in France is 9 minutes [source].
The volume of water used in a shower is 135 L.

Formula: Volume [L] = flow rate [L/min] x time [minutes]
Details: 15 * 9 = 135

title: GPT-J
description:
To estimate the carbon footprint of GPT-J, a freely available language model with 6 billion parameters, Raghavendra Selvan ran experiments on a local workstation. The model was initialized in half-precision (16 bit float instead of 32 bit float) to fit into GPU memory. The average length of text generated by the model was 230 words. The energy consumption got measured with CarbonTracker, a tool developed by researchers from University of Copenhagen.

As a result, one request to GPT-J consumed in average 0.01292 kWh.
